ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic principles in all engineering disciplines, especially electrical engineering and computer science

I learned a lot in this course- not only about the different types of engineering, but how to 3d print, laser cut, and solder.  I also learned how to think like an engineer and be precise in my work so later problems don't crop up from previous mistakes.
I learned about the basic ideas of each type of engineering. I learned how to code better, CAD 3D models, and solder. Overall, I would say this course covers good basic engineering knowledge.

I learned very briefly what various engineering fields do (electrical, mechanical, chemical, biomedical, and environmental). I also gained a very rudimentary understanding of coding (through processing and arduino), CAD (using onshape), and basic circuits. I also learned what a basic engineering process looks like.
Basics of engineering and the numerous disciplines it entails

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very intensive and interactive, nothing to improve as the workload is necessarily for the purposes of the course

Strengths:
- The final project forced me to learn and apply so many skills. It was a lot of work, but I learned so much from it that it was 100% worth it. 
- Larry is an incredibly instructor, and spends so much time with every student.  
-Lab section was enjoyable and taught me a lot of skills that I utilized later in the course.
Weaknesses:
- Lectures in the beginning of the course weren't necessarily super helpful.

I needed a lot of extra help during this course. Because there are only 2 teachers, some time was spent waiting for them to finish helping other students. Of course this makes sense! But just something to keep in mind.

This course had a LOT of outside-of-class work. The professors also graded based on their own criteria rather than the criteria of the clients for the final project which was annoying: we essentially had two clients who often wanted different (and sometimes even conflicting) outcomes. Also, grading often depended on the amount of time the professors saw you working in the CEID rather on the amount of work completed.
The amount of work expected for the projects is extremely high and it is difficult to balance other academic related pursuits as well as devote enough time to earn a reasonable participation grade.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they would be ok with the workload yes

Yes, if you are looking to go into engineering, but you don't know what type or you don't feel like you have a lot of technical skills, this course is for you.  You will learn a lot, and you will also get a good idea of what the different engineering fields do.

I would recommend this course if you are able to allot hours outside of classroom time for the projects. I spend a ton of time working with my team in office hours but found it to be extremely rewarding.
Take this class if you want to get a basic understanding of what engineering looks like. Just be prepared for a LOT of work.
